section.title: Actuarial Notation 1 -- v
section.p: Actuaries have their own notation that they use for finance. Their notation can often declutter formulas, but at a price of making them more difficult to understand.
We have already met some actuarial notation. The symbol \iota^{(n)} is actuarial notation for a nominal interest rate. Our next bit of actuarial notation concerns present values.

In this course, you will find that present value formulas are often more elegant than their future value equivalents. Recall that the present value A(0) is related to the future value A(n) at time n (written a little differently) is A(0) = A(n) \frac{1}{(1+i)^n} The expression \frac{1}{1+i} is called the present value factor, and by itself is clunky to work with. Actuaries use v for the present value factor. In this activity, we will explore the advantage and disadvantage of this notation.

introduction.p: An annuity (more precisely, annuity-immediate) is a sequence of payments made at the end of each period over a length of time. We want the payments to be equally spaced, meaning the time between each payment is the same. We will denote the payment amount by K (which for now we assume to be constant), and the number of payments to be n. This means we have payments of K at the end of times 1, 2, \ldots, n.

section.p: Recall from calculus that a geometric series is a series of the form \sum_{t=0}^{n-1} ar^k While we will review geometric series later in this book, for now we will use the following formula to sum from 1 to n: \sum_{t=1}^n ar^k = a r \left(\frac{1-r^n}{1-r}\right)

introduction.p: Actuaries us v for the present value factor: v = \frac{1}{1+i} If there is more than one interest rate (like \iota and j), we put subscripts on v: v_{\iota} and v_{j}.

introduction.p: Annuities show up throughout this course. Here are a couple of examples.

task.p: is about loans. If someone is paying back a loan, the outstanding balance after the tth payment is the present value (at time t) of the remaining n-t payments. This is called the prospective form of the outstanding balance formula (it looks forward, prospectively, to the upcoming payments). Using K for the payments, and using interest rate \iota, find a formula for the outstanding balance after t payments.

li.p: an equally-spaced sequence of n payments of K, called coupon payments, followed by
a final lump sum C paid with the last coupon payment called the redemption amount.

task.p: The coupon payments use a rate r called the coupon rate applied to something called the face value F. So the coupon payments are rF (often F = C). The interest rate \iota is used for valuation, and often \iota \neq r.

The price of the bond is the present value of the coupon payments and the redemption amount. Find a formula for the price P of a bond with coupon payments of K, redemption amount C, and interest rate \iota.
